title: Fix PowerShell terminal suggestion performance by deduplicating concurrent requests
body:
This PR fixes a critical performance issue where PowerShell terminal suggestions spawn multiple concurrent `pwsh` processes when users request completions, overwhelming the system.

## Problem

When terminal suggestions are enabled (`terminal.integrated.suggest.enabled: true`) and a user presses Ctrl+Space for completions, VS Code can spawn multiple `pwsh -c "Get-Command -All | ..."` processes simultaneously. This creates a "thundering herd" problem because:

- Multiple completion requests arrive concurrently (rapid key presses, multiple windows, terminal restoration, etc.)
- Each request spawns its own PowerShell process instead of waiting for existing ones
- For users with many commands (40k+ in the reported case), each process takes 13-19 seconds
- Multiple processes consume massive CPU/memory resources and can crash systems

## Root Cause

The issue occurs in `fetchAndCacheShellGlobals()` where concurrent requests for the same cache key (machine + shell type) each spawn separate PowerShell processes instead of sharing a single request.

## Solution

Implemented request deduplication using an in-flight requests map:

1. **Added `inflightRequests` Map**: Tracks pending requests by cache key
2. **Request Deduplication**: Before spawning a new PowerShell process, check if one is already running for the same cache key
3. **Promise Sharing**: Multiple concurrent requests now await the same Promise instead of spawning separate processes
4. **Proper Cleanup**: Promises are removed from the map when complete to prevent memory leaks

```typescript
// Check if there's already an in-flight request for this cache key
const existingRequest = inflightRequests.get(cacheKey);
if (existingRequest) {
    // Wait for the existing request to complete rather than spawning a new process
    return existingRequest;
}
```

## Performance Impact

**Before:**
- 5 concurrent requests = 5 PowerShell processes = 65-95 seconds CPU time
- System overwhelmed with multiple long-running processes

**After:**
- 5 concurrent requests = 1 PowerShell process = 13-19 seconds total
- ~80% reduction in CPU/memory usage
- System remains responsive

## Validation

The fix has been thoroughly tested to ensure:
- ✅ Multiple concurrent requests for same cache key → Only 1 PowerShell process
- ✅ Different cache keys (different shells/machines) → Separate processes as expected  
- ✅ Proper cleanup → No memory leaks
- ✅ Maintains existing caching behavior (7-day cache)
- ✅ No breaking changes to functionality

This follows the same deduplication pattern used elsewhere in VS Code's codebase for similar scenarios.

Fixes #256746.

body:
from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256833

> This first issue is a serious one. When I type, delete, or replace text in a document (for example, in a Python script), the change is not immediately reported by the screen reader. The change does occur visually on the screen, but it's as if NVDA is frozen until I move the cursor away from and then back to the modified area.
> 
> This also happens when pasting text. For example:
> I am at the beginning of a line that I want to replace. I select the entire line with Shift+End, and the selection is read correctly. I then paste with Ctrl+V, and absolutely nothing happens—there is no speech feedback and no update on my Braille display. However, if I move the cursor vertically off the line and then back onto it, I can confirm that the text has been replaced correctly. This behavior is incredibly disruptive and is ruining my user experience with VSCode, which is my favorite piece of software and is always running on all my computers.

from @GabrieleBattaglia

title: Search String Only in Files Changed (Uncommitted) via Git

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
**Problem:**
Currently in VS Code, there is no built-in way to search for a string only within files that are modified but not yet committed (i.e., tracked by Git but with changes in the working tree or index).

**Workaround:**
A common workaround involves using the terminal:

_git diff --name-only_

Then copying that list into the “files to include” field in VS Code's search panel. However, this is manual, error-prone, and repetitive.

Proposed Feature:
Add a built-in filter/scope option in the Global Search panel:

🔍 Search only in files with uncommitted Git changes

This filter would automatically:

Detect files listed by git diff --name-only.

Limit the search scope to these files.

Benefits:

- Speeds up debugging and code review workflows.
- Helps in focused refactoring.
- Makes Git integration in VS Code even more powerful.

title: Fix remote and multi-root issues with task tools
body: 1) Task tools weren't working for remotes It can take longer in a remote window for the tasks service to update after a config change, such as when a task is added to the `tasks.json`. Before, we had a static timeout of 200 ms. Now, we poll for up to 5 seconds to wait for the task to be discovered. The key for tasks in a remote window is different from the local case, so we have to parse the URI to check for the workspace folder 2) Task tools weren't working for mult-root repos, just needed to loop over all folders to find task config fixes #258720 fixes #258723 fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259014

title: Fix ctrl+a in Kusto notebook cells triggering selectAllOutput instead of text selection
body:
When users double-click a Kusto notebook cell with "Properties" details and focus the cell input, pressing `ctrl+a` was incorrectly triggering the `notebook.cell.output.selectAll` command instead of performing normal text selection within the input field.

## Root Cause

The keybinding condition for `notebook.cell.output.selectAll` was too broad:

```typescript
when: ContextKeyExpr.and(NOTEBOOK_EDITOR_FOCUSED, NOTEBOOK_OUTPUT_FOCUSED)
```

This condition matched both:
- When focus is on actual output content (correct behavior)
- When focus is on an input field within the output (incorrect behavior)

## Solution

Added `NOTEBOOK_OUTPUT_INPUT_FOCUSED.toNegated()` to the keybinding condition:

```typescript
when: ContextKeyExpr.and(NOTEBOOK_EDITOR_FOCUSED, NOTEBOOK_OUTPUT_FOCUSED, NOTEBOOK_OUTPUT_INPUT_FOCUSED.toNegated())
```

This ensures the `selectAll` command only triggers when:
- The notebook editor is focused
- Some output is focused  
- **But not when an input field within the output has focus**

This pattern follows the same approach used in other notebook keybindings throughout the codebase (e.g., in `editActions.ts`).

## Impact

- ✅ `ctrl+a` in Kusto notebook cell inputs now performs normal text selection
- ✅ `notebook.cell.output.selectAll` still works correctly when focused on actual output content
- ✅ No regression to existing notebook functionality

Fixes #252236.

title: Support wildcards in Settings editor ID search with @id:prefix.* syntax
body:
The Settings editor now supports wildcard patterns for ID filtering, allowing users to search for groups of related settings using the `@id:prefix.*` syntax.

## What's Changed

Previously, the Settings editor only supported exact ID matching:
```
@id:files.autoSave  → Shows only files.autoSave
```

Now it also supports wildcard patterns:
```
@id:files.*         → Shows all settings starting with "files."
@id:editor.format.* → Shows all editor format-related settings
@id:terminal.*      → Shows all terminal settings
```

## Implementation

The change modifies the `matchesAnyId` method in `SettingsTreeSettingElement` to:

1. **Check exact matches first** (maintains existing performance and compatibility)
2. **Detect wildcard patterns** ending with `.*`
3. **Use prefix matching** by removing the `.*` suffix and checking if the setting key starts with the prefix

## Examples

| Search Query | Matches |
|-------------|---------|
| `@id:editor.*` | `editor.formatOnSave`, `editor.fontSize`, `editor.wordWrap` |
| `@id:files.*` | `files.autoSave`, `files.encoding`, `files.exclude` |
| `@id:terminal.integrated.*` | `terminal.integrated.shell`, `terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell` |
| `@id:debug.*,files.autoSave` | All debug settings + exact match for files.autoSave |

## Benefits

- **Better discoverability**: Users can explore setting categories without knowing exact names
- **Extension settings**: Easy discovery with `@id:extensionName.*`
- **Grouped configuration**: Configure related settings together
- **Zero breaking changes**: All existing queries work unchanged

## Testing

Added comprehensive test coverage including:
- Exact matching (backward compatibility)
- Basic wildcard patterns
- Specific prefixes
- Multiple and mixed filters
- Edge cases

Fixes #242231.

> - Add the appropriate URLs or hosts to the custom allowlist in this repository's [Copilot coding agent settings](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/settings/copilot/coding_agent) (admins only)
>
> </details>

title: Doesn't follow instruction

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

labels.name: chat-prompts
labels.description: Prompt and Instruction files related issues

body:
Type: Bug Problem Description GitHub Copilot frequently fails to adhere to general, project-level instructions provided in a dedicated instruction file. Despite clear directives in this file, Copilot generates suggestions that contradict these established guidelines, forcing manual corrections and repeated prompting. This behavior significantly undermines the purpose of having a centralized instruction file and leads to wasted "turns" and decreased development efficiency. Expected Behavior Copilot should consistently read, interpret, and strictly follow the instructions defined in a project-level instruction file. These guidelines should influence all code suggestions made within that repository or project, acting as a foundational set of rules. Actual Behavior Copilot often appears to ignore or give low priority to instructions contained within the project's designated instruction file. This results in: Violations of coding standards: Suggestions that do not conform to specified naming conventions, code formatting, or architectural patterns outlined in the instruction file. Incorrect technology/library usage: Recommending disallowed libraries, frameworks, or methods when the instruction file explicitly prohibits them or mandates alternatives. Inconsistent behavior: Sometimes, Copilot might follow the instructions, but often it reverts to default behaviors or context-specific interpretations that override the project-level guidelines. This issue forces developers to manually enforce rules that should be automated by Copilot, adding overhead and negating the benefits of an AI assistant for maintaining code quality and consistency. <!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When I clone and open a repository in VS Code for the first time and the repo has a devcontainer config, VS Code suggests to open the repo in the dev container. I almost always choose this option as I really like dev containers
Once VS Code has built the dev container, the right bottom part of the window opens a terminal which is also great
Only thing is that this terminal view is split and to the left of it, there is the ports view for the forwarded ports. I usually don't need this an it steals a lot of space from the terminal. I want to be able to specify what views are open by default on a new devcontainer and how much space they can occupy and where.

Ideally this should be in the user settings and be applied to all dev containers

title: Add UI entry point for terminal auto-approve dropdown
body:
This PR adds a dropdown menu to the terminal command confirmation dialog, allowing users to quickly configure auto-approval settings for commands. Previously, users had to manually edit settings to add commands to the auto-approve list - now they can do it directly from the confirmation dialog.

## Implementation

When a terminal command requires confirmation, the "Continue" button now includes a dropdown with contextual options:

- **Always allow `[exact command]`** - Adds the specific command to the auto-approve list
- **Always allow `[base command]` commands** - Adds the base command (e.g., `npm`) to approve all commands starting with it (only shown for multi-word commands)
- **Configure auto approve...** - Opens the settings page for advanced configuration

Similar to workspace trust dialogs, the dropdown provides smart options based on the command structure:

```javascript
// For "npm run build":
[
  { label: "Always allow `npm run build`", type: "exact" },
  { label: "Always allow `npm` commands", type: "prefix" }, 
  { label: "Configure auto approve...", type: "configure" }
]

// For single commands like "git":
[
  { label: "Always allow `git`", type: "exact" },
  { label: "Configure auto approve...", type: "configure" }
]
```

## Technical Details

- Extended `IToolConfirmationMessages` interface with `customActions` property
- Added `_generateAutoApproveActions()` method in `RunInTerminalTool` to create contextual dropdown options
- Enhanced `ToolConfirmationSubPart` to handle custom actions and update the `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove` configuration
- Leverages existing `moreActions` dropdown infrastructure from the confirmation widget
- Includes comprehensive tests for various command scenarios

The feature integrates seamlessly with the existing auto-approval system and maintains consistency with VS Code's confirmation dialog patterns.

![Terminal confirmation dialog showing the new dropdown options](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2c3330cb-9b29-4bbb-95a5-a61d1dc968e8)

Fixes #253268.

title: Debugger not correctly escaping paths
body:
Type: Bug I want to try and debug a node.js program. However, the debugger seems to be unable to correctly parse some folders. I have spent hours upon hours to investigate the issue, creating different launch configs, trying multiple versions of node, reinstalling VS code etc. Nothing seems to fix it. Together with **copilot** i have come to the conclusion that this is actually a bug with the vscode debugger. The debugger seems to improperly escape file paths in node options, so it can't properly parse filepaths with spaces. To reproduce 1. Install vscode in a folder with spaces (Such as C:/Program Files/Microsoft VS Code 2. try to debug a node package instead of a direct .js file, such as the CommandKit CLI. 3. Watch the errors coming Example of the errors: ${env:NODE_OPTIONS}=' --require "c:/Program Files/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/extensions/ms-vscode.js-debug/src/bootloader.js" --inspect-publish-uid=http'; ${env:VSCODE_INSPECTOR_OPTIONS}=':::{"inspectorIpc":"\\\\.\\pipe\\node-cdp.22156-f2b95b0f-9.sock","deferredMode":false,"waitForDebugger":"","execPath":"C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node.exe","onlyEntrypoint":false,"autoAttachMode":"always","fileCallback":"C:\\Users\\jespe\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\node-debug-callback-a0401281ee7a9701"}'; & 'C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.cmd' 'run' 'dev' Debugger attached. > commandkit-app@0.0.0 dev > commandkit dev Debugger attached. title: Add New Terminal option to editor tab well context menu
body:
This PR adds a "New Terminal" option to the context menu that appears when right-clicking in the empty area to the right of editor tabs, as requested in the issue.

## Changes Made

- Added a new menu item to `MenuId.EmptyEditorGroupContext` that calls the existing `workbench.action.createTerminalEditorSameGroup` command
- Used the existing `terminalStrings.new` localization for consistency with other terminal UI elements
- Added `TerminalContextKeys.processSupported` condition to ensure the menu item only appears when terminals are supported in the current workspace
- Positioned the menu item in group `'1_create'` with order 10 to appear at the top of the context menu

## Implementation Details

The implementation reuses existing VS Code infrastructure:
- **Command**: Uses the existing terminal command that creates a terminal in the same editor group
- **Localization**: Leverages the existing "New Terminal" string used throughout the terminal UI  
- **Conditioning**: Follows the same pattern as other terminal menu items by checking process support

When users right-click in the empty editor tab area, they will now see a "New Terminal" option at the top of the context menu. Selecting it creates a new terminal editor in that editor group, providing a convenient way to add terminals directly to the desired editor location.

The changes are minimal (3 lines of code) and follow established VS Code patterns for menu contributions.

Fixes #259002.

title: Fix terminal creation in auxiliary windows when using Ctrl+Shift+`
body:
When a terminal is moved into a new window using "Move Terminal into New Window" and then the "Create New Terminal" command (Ctrl+Shift+`) is executed from that auxiliary window, the terminal was incorrectly being created in the original main window instead of the current auxiliary window.

## Problem

The issue occurred because the `TerminalCommandId.New` action did not consider which window context it was running in. It would always fall back to the terminal service's `defaultLocation` (Panel or Editor based on configuration), which targets the main window.

## Solution

Modified the terminal creation logic in `terminalActions.ts` to:

1. **Detect auxiliary window context** using VS Code's built-in `IsAuxiliaryWindowContext` context key
2. **Target the current auxiliary window** by setting the terminal location to the active editor group in that window using `editorGroupToColumn(editorGroupsService, editorGroupsService.activeGroup)`
3. **Preserve existing behavior** for main windows and when explicit locations are already specified

## Changes

- Added imports for `IContextKeyService` and `IsAuxiliaryWindowContext`
- Added auxiliary window detection logic in the `TerminalCommandId.New` action handler
- When in an auxiliary window and no explicit location is provided, the terminal is now created in that window's editor area

The fix is minimal and conservative - it only changes behavior for auxiliary windows and only when no explicit location is specified, ensuring no regressions in existing functionality.

Fixes #259000.

title: Run in terminal: Trying to run first command without shell integration may not execute

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
Repro:

1. Windows, pwsh 7
2. Open a powershell terminal, if it takes less than a second to launch you need to open your profile (`code $PROFILE`) and add `Start-Sleep 2`
3. Close all terminals
4. Disable shell integration `"terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled": false`
5. Reload window (this is important as it's related to caching)
6. Ask `run ls in terminal`, note the start up time of pwsh
7. Close the terminal
8. Repeat 6, 🐛 if it takes over a second to initialize it may not actually run 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e6319863-5296-4957-b2fa-22a1410a776f)

title: Remove trailing empty lines from mainThreadChatStatus.ts
body:
This PR removes unnecessary trailing empty lines from the `mainThreadChatStatus.ts` file to maintain consistent code formatting throughout the VS Code codebase.

## Changes Made

- Removed 3 trailing empty lines at the end of `src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadChatStatus.ts`
- The file now ends with a single newline after the closing brace, following the coding standards of the VS Code repository

## Why This Change

The file previously had multiple empty lines at the end:
```typescript
	$disposeEntry(id: string): void {
		this._chatStatusItemService.deleteEntry(id);
	}
}



```

Now it properly ends with just a single newline:
```typescript
	$disposeEntry(id: string): void {
		this._chatStatusItemService.deleteEntry(id);
	}
}
```

This helps maintain a clean and consistent codebase by removing unnecessary whitespace, which is important for:
- Code readability and consistency

title: can't use copilot chat premium
body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version: 1.102.2
- OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.5.0
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): all of them
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): all but GPT 4.1
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  just try to use it

on July 22nd my copilot pro subscription renewed and when i tried to use it on July 23rd, it said 
"You have exceeded your premium request allowance. We have automatically switched you to GPT-4.1 which is included with your plan."

There are lots of people experiencing the same thing. On github support at last told that copilot chat extension is maintaned by vscode so i've been redirected to here. 

What is the real problem and how will it be solved?
Thanks in advance,

title: conflict diff coloring
body:
Currently color is red for the original, green for current change and blue for incoming

```diff
<<<<<<< HEAD (current change)
ab
||||||| 1075d698
a
=======
ca
>>>>>>> main (incoming)
```

What would be epic: if the original was not colored, and the current and incoming are colored green/red where parts are inserted or deleted. (At the moment it's hard to see what the differences are from the original.) In this example the 'c' and the 'b' would be highlighted in green.
